Can you imagine what the executive branch would do to conservative legislators?

Can you imagine the frivolous lawsuits for defamation that would be brought against legislators by outside political actors?

Our government would fail quickly.

Because Courts have given Congress broad latitude to interpret ‚ÄúEach House may determine the Rules of its Proceedings,‚Äù Congress must exercise excruciating discernment in this domain.

Congressmen have power only because of the Constitution. If we ignore it, we have no power.

Freedom of speech is paramount in a republican government.

US Constitution:

‚ÄúRepresentatives‚Ä¶ for any Speech or Debate‚Ä¶ shall not be questioned in any other Place.‚Äù

Members are constitutionally authorized to say that which could be considered defamatory or illegal elsewhere.

Any combination of actions that violates the Constitution is in fact a violation.

A 2/3 vote is required to expel a member.

But a fine, whether taken from a member or his campaign account, so great as to force a member to leave, is effectively unconstitutional expulsion by 1/2.

There are reasonable arguments to be made that the 1st Amendment, freedom of speech, and the 5th Amendment, due process, also limit the methods and reasons Congress can employ to punish its own members.

Congress must itself abide by the spirit and letter of the ultimate law.

In 2021, members, including myself, were fined and their salaries reduced for refusal to wear a mask.

Whether this was constitutional is the subject of an ongoing federal lawsuit.

This is a ‚Äúcase of first impression,‚Äù which means no prior court decision has settled this matter.

27A did not limit activity before 1992, the year of its ratification.

If members do not voluntarily pay, no existing law enables Congress to confiscate money from members.

Censure, Expulsion by 2/3 vote, or pay deductions could possibly be tried to motivate payment of fines.

27A states:

‚ÄúNo law, varying the compensation for the services of the Senators and Representatives, shall take effect, until an election of Representatives shall have intervened.‚Äù

Congress cannot vary a member‚Äôs salary unless Congress has sat for re-election at the ballot box.

In fact, 8A and 27A have this effect.

8A states:

‚ÄúExcessive bail shall not be required, nor excessive fines imposed, nor cruel and unusual punishments inflicted.‚Äù

Therefore, Congress can‚Äôt levy an excessive fine on a member nor can they draw and quarter a member as punishment.

If the Constitution were amended to say,

‚ÄúNo member can be fined an excessive amount as punishment.‚Äù

or

‚ÄúSalary reductions to enforce fines, can‚Äôt be enacted without an intervening election.‚Äù

These amendments would limit what could be done according to Art 1, Sec 5, Clause 2.

Art 1, Sec 5, Clause 2 of the Constitution states:

When our Constitution is amended, everything in the Constitution that precedes the amendment is subject to the amendment.
